                                                    Politico
A daily overview of education policy news

            By 
Caitlin Emma

09/17/15, 10:00 AM EDT
With help from Allie Grasgreen, Kimberly Hefling, Maggie Severns, Adam Sneed and Aubree Eliza Weaver
EDUCATION A NO-SHOW AT GOP DEBATE: Education didn’t just take a backseat during Thursday night’s GOP presidential debate — it wasn’t invited along for the ride. There were zero questions about education over the course of the second, three-hour debate hosted by CNN. And none of the Republican candidates focused on the issue in any substantial way. Education only received fleeting mentions amid a debate heavy on immigration, national security, defense and other issues. (Your Morning Education author could swear a Common Core question was coming when moderator Hugh Hewitt asked Jeb Bush about the “elephant in the room.” But alas, no.) POLITICO fact-checked the candidates on a range of issues here: http://politi.co/1W4gnHQ. And here are a few highlights from education’s sudden and short-lived moment in the spotlight:
— Donald Trump randomly knocked Jeb Bush on the Common Core, noting that Bush supports the standards despite the fact that they’re a “complete disaster.”
— Trump and Bush then sparred over speaking Spanish, with Trump insisting that immigrants speak English if they want to assimilate in the U.S. Bush then praised “the largest voucher program in the country,” referring to Florida’s tax credit scholarship program established in 2001 when he was governor. If one of those voucher students asks him a question in Spanish, then he’s going to answer in Spanish, he said. 
— Trump at one point inaccurately linked childhood vaccines to autism, calling for “smaller doses over a longer period of time … We’ve had so many instances — people that work for me, just the other day. Two years old, 2 1/2 years old, a child, a beautiful child, went to have the vaccine, and came back and a week later got a tremendous fever, got very, very sick, now is autistic.” Ben Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, said there’s “extremely well-documented proof” that there’s “no correlation between vaccination and autism.” Rand Paul said he’s “all for vaccines but I’m also for freedom ... I should be able to spread out vaccines if I want to.” The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said that giving children multiple shots at the same time is proven to be safe.
— Carson also knocked the Obama administration’s free community college proposal, saying that it’s fiscally irresponsible and it could destabilize the country. 
— Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker said several times that he came out on top after his 2011 brawl with labor unions, including teachers unions, saying he refused to back down even amid a recall effort. He also panned liberal efforts to raise the minimum wage, saying it makes more sense to give people a better education, among other things.
— During the earlier debate for the lower-profile contenders, former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum linked Kentucky clerk Kim Davis’ faith and refusal to provide marriage licenses to gay couples to Columbine student Cassie Bernall. Santorum said Bernall’s “yes” answer to one of the shooter’s questions about whether she believed in God led to her death. But that story has been widely debunked, with investigators in Jefferson County, Colo., saying it was someone else — who survived — who faced that scenario. 
— Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal said he didn’t think Texas high school freshman Ahmed Mohamed should’ve been arrested [http://politi.co/1Qi3CWq] for bringing a homemade clock to school, which Irving, Texas, Police Chief Larry Boyd called a “hoax bomb.” 
SPEAKING OF 2016 ... NO CANDIDATE LEFT BEHIND: Hillary Clinton took a dig at Republicans on immigration, writing of meeting with DREAMers on Cinco de Mayo this year at a Las Vegas high school. In a column posted on a Univision site, she said the “political debate over immigration has never been easy,” but that she left the meeting thinking that if others could hear the young people she met, “the debate would be over.” She went on: “I didn’t expect that this summer, the Republican primary would come to seem less like a competition for the highest office in the land and more like a race to see who can make the most hostile, outlandish, vitriolic claims about the immigrant community. I won’t repeat their comments here. I will only say: America is better than this.” More here: http://bit.ly/1iwOVEs 
— On campus sexual assault, Sen. Bernie Sanders quietly signed onto a Senate bill to address the problem right after Clinton delivered a speech highlighting the issue, according to The College Fix: http://bit.ly/1NDXEl6
— ICYMI: Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush recently unveiled a political network for college students in an effort to boost support among millennials. About 135 campus chapters are already in place across 36 states, CNN reports: http://cnn.it/1W4dI11. (h/t Young Invincibles)
— Republican Sen. Rand Paul said last week at Iowa State University that his campaign has met its goal of establishing 300 student groups within 30 days. The Blaze: http://bit.ly/1LhK70J. 
GOOD THURSDAY MORNING, SEPT. 17. If you were a fan of Disney’s classic, “The Jungle Book,” then you have to watch this trailer for the live-action remake: http://bit.ly/1isQt2i. Stick around for the last few seconds — it gave me chills! [http://bit.ly/1klctdC] Don’t forget to send tips, clips and amusing GIFs to cemma@politico.com or @caitlinzemma. Send events to: educalendar@politicopro.com. And follow us on Twitter: @Morning_Edu and @POLITICOPro.
POLITICO’S WHAT WORKS D.C.: Join POLITICO Magazine for the next in their What Works series, focusing on the future of Washington, D.C. Featured speakers include: Nashville Mayor Karl Dean, Delegated Deputy Secretary John King, Department of Education; Karen Mills, former administrator of the U.S. Small Business Administration and senior fellow at Harvard University; and more. Find out more http://politi.co/1LgPvkI and RSVP here.
RANKINGS BEST ED DEPARTMENT: Just 16 percent of prospective students use Education Department resources like College Navigator in their college search — but 80 percent of those who do find them helpful, a new survey says. That’s more positive feedback than students give high school guidance counselors or teachers. And department officials — unlike many colleges — will be pleased to hear that only 23 percent of respondents used rankings like U.S. News & World Report’s, though higher-income students were more likely to do so. The fifth and final brief in New America’s College Decisions Survey series focuses on how prospective students gather information and what resources they find most useful. The report says college websites and online search engines are the most popular resources — actual campus visits rank a distant third. White students were significantly more likely to consult their parents than are their peers of other races. Hispanic and low-income students were also most likely to say they didn’t get enough information through their research. New America is live-streaming a 9 a.m. ET presentation and panel on the paper: http://bit.ly/1JyrWPT.
— Moving on to graduate students: 2014 was a record-breaking year for applications, offers of admission and enrollment of first-time grad students, which grew 3.5 percent overall, according to a new Council of Graduate Schools report: http://bit.ly/1FNv3Ss.
— The Upshot ranks the top colleges doing the most for low-income students: http://nyti.ms/1iQhD3d. 
YOU’RE INVITED: POLITICO Magazine is hosting an event on Sept. 22 about the future of cities and the role of education: How do cities build a skilled urban workforce for the jobs of today and tomorrow? What does it take for community colleges to become a path to success — and should tuition be free? What have we learned about charter schools and their effect on low-income neighborhoods? Participants include John King, senior advisor delegated duties of deputy secretary of education at the Education Department, and others. Details: http://politi.co/1JQS9t5. 
COOL CLOCK, AHMED: The Texas teenager who was arrested after he brought a homemade clock to school might be headed to D.C. and Silicon Valley. ICYMI, 14-year-old Ahmed Mohamed found himself in handcuffs when a teacher spotted his clock and alerted police, mistaking it for a bomb. The resulting firestorm got lots of attention, including from the White House. After President Barack Obama invited [http://politi.co/1Qi3CWq] Ahmed to drop by for a visit, U.S. Chief Data Scientist D.J. Patil wrote about his experience growing up, making things and showing them off to his teachers [http://1.usa.gov/1NDY4Yx]. OSTP Director John Holdren also invited Ahmed to attend the White House Astronomy Night on Oct. 19. Education Secretary Arne Duncan tweeted [http://bit.ly/1Ki9f3i], “We need to be encouraging young engineers, not putting them in handcuffs. #IStandWithAhmed.” 
— The tech world got in on the action, too. Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg extended an invitation to visit Facebook and saying, “Having the skill and ambition to build something cool should lead to applause, not arrest.” [http://on.fb.me/1W3Y6KQ] Twitter went one step further, asking Ahmed if he’d consider being an intern [http://bit.ly/1NDZaUb]. 
— The Texas teenager is likely going to transfer schools following his arrest, The Texas Tribune reports: http://bit.ly/1JcDBCi. 
CHILDREN IN POVERTY: More than one in five children under 18 lived in poverty. That adds up to about 15.5 million children, according to new U.S. Census Bureau [http://1.usa.gov/1KROvVH] figures. The poverty rate for families was 11.6 percent, with an estimated 9.5 million families living in poverty. These figures for 2014 are relatively unchanged from a year earlier. The Census Bureau also reported that the number of people who go without health insurance declined. 
— Three quarters of California elementary students with chronic attendance problems come from low-income families, according to the third annual report on elementary school truancy released by California Attorney General Kamala Harris on Wednesday. Find it here: http://bit.ly/1OZgwIA. 
SEVEN SCIENTISTS TO BE CELEBRATED FOR ‘ODD’ BUT IMPORTANT RESEARCH: Crowds will gather in Washington this evening to honor seven scientists who have conducted federally funded research that’s had a major health, economic and social effect. At a time when politicians often question why government should fund research projects that lack obvious practical benefits, the Golden Goose Award is intended to highlight the “unpredictable nature of basic scientific research and the fact that some of the most important scientific discoveries come from federally funded research that may once have been viewed as unusual, odd or obscure.” 
— The 2015 recipients are: Walter Mischel, Yuichi Shoda and Philip Peake for their creation of the classic “marshmallow test,” which led to the development of techniques to boost self-control; Torsten Wiesel and the late David Hubel for their Nobel-prize winning project on neuroplasticity that started with showing moving lights to cats; and Joel E. Cohen and Christopher Small, whose work studying the distribution of human population by altitude ultimately aided disaster preparedness. The ceremony is set to begin at 5:30 p.m. ET, with Frank Sesno, former CNN anchor and director of the George Washington University School of Media and Public Affairs, serving as the master of ceremonies.
IT’S CONSTITUTION DAY! Today is Constitution Day, and the National Constitution Center and the College Board are launching a new online tool called the Interactive Constitution. Users will be able to click on any provision of the U.S. Constitution and read what leading scholars from across the philosophical and political spectrum have to say about its meaning. The Interactive Constitution will also be a featured tool in a number of Advanced Placement history and government courses. “America’s Founding Documents, and the Constitution in particular, have inspired a great conversation about freedom, justice, and human dignity that continues to this day,” said College Board president and CEO David Coleman. “It is a conversation that we need more students to be prepared to join through the careful study of these remarkable documents.”
MICROSOFT’S COMPUTER SCIENCE COMMITMENT: A day after New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio called for all public schools to phase in computer science over the next 10 years, Microsoft announced a new $75 million, global commitment toward expanding access to computer science. Part of that commitment is an expansion of Microsoft’s Technology Education and Literacy in Schools program, which teams up tech professionals with educators to teach computer science in U.S. high schools. Microsoft hopes to grow the TEALS program fivefold over the next three years, “with the goal of working with 2,000 tech industry volunteers to reach 30,000 students in nearly 700 schools across 33 states,” the company said in a statement. Read more: http://bit.ly/1Ms1NIr. 
READY, SET, CRAWL: Toddlers wearing race bibs will “run” a relay race outside the Capitol this morning to make a statement on how child care “sets the pace” for children's’ futures. Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash); Sen. Bob Casey (D-Pa.); Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.); Rep. David Price (D-N.C.); Education Department Deputy Assistant Secretary Libby Doggett are all slated to attend. The event is being put on by the advocacy group MomsRising.org and the National Women’s Law Center.
— On a related note: Too Small to Fail, a joint initiative of the Clinton Foundation and Next Generation, announced Wednesday that it’s expanding its work on early language and brain development to include early math. “Talking to young children about early math concepts like numeracy early on not only helps their brains develop, but can help their confidence with math later on in school.” said Patti Miller, director of Too Small to Fail. “By providing parents and caregivers with resources to make the most of everyday moments to talk about math, we believe we can strengthen a young child’s understanding of the world around them and help them succeed in school.” Find more here: http://bit.ly/1Ycvr8k. 
MOVERS AND SHAKERS 
— Laurie Calvert has been tapped as education policy adviser to Learning Forward and the National Commission on Teaching and America’s Future. Calvert most recently worked as a teacher liaison at the Education Department.
— The Alliance for Excellent Education has hired Stephanie Wood-Garnett as vice president of policy and advocacy: http://bit.ly/1FNV9or. 
— Jazzy Wright, press officer for the American Library Association’s Washington office, is leaving the association for a new venture. Nancy Gravatt has been hired as the new press officer.
SYLLABUS
— New York City Mayor Bill De Blasio maps out his K-12 education agenda. POLITICO New York: http://politi.co/1KSudv0 
— Future Florida House speaker: State should “fully fund” school choice. redefinED: http://bit.ly/1QiJNya 
— Indiana Attorney General deals blow to plan that would spare schools with low test scores. The Associated Press: http://bit.ly/1QiXJZ9 
— School nurses stock drug to reverse opioid overdoses. NPR: http://n.pr/1ixdWzw 
— Alaska Supreme Court hears arguments in education funding lawsuit. KRBD: http://bit.ly/1iiChZc 
— Spurred by Seattle teachers strike support, groups continue education fight. The Seattle Times: http://bit.ly/1UXWGob 
— Rejecting Indiana Superintendent Glenda Ritz’s logic, state board promises A-to-F grades will be issued. Chalkbeat Indiana: http://bit.ly/1FhuwNq 
— KIPP’s explosive growth came with slight dip in performance. The Washington Post: http://wapo.st/1Li5UW4 
— Florida Department of Law Enforcement ends its investigation into state testing disruptions. Tampa Bay Times: http://bit.ly/1Og9cuV 
— UW-Madison faculty suspicious of Chicago professor's survey on tenure. The Capital Times: http://bit.ly/1KSwk1X 
— Indiana high school senior to U.S. Secretary of Education: Help me get to college. Chalkbeat Indiana: http://bit.ly/1W4srsM 
— North Carolina lawmakers agree to change the laws governing the oversight and approval of the state's rapidly growing charter schools. The Associated Press: http://bit.ly/1McFKT8 
— Arkansas Baptist College is in jeopardy of losing its accreditation, in part because of its debt, even though it secured a $30 million federal loan last year to shore up its finances. Arkansas Online: http://bit.ly/1P0RbOr 
The Pro Education team is all you've ever wanted [http://bit.ly/1FOhkP0] and it's all that you want still: @MLBombard or mbombardieri@politico.com, @CaitlinZEmma or cemma@politico.com, @alliegrasgreen or agrasgreen@politico.com, @khefling or khefling@politico.com, @MaggieSeverns or mseverns@politico.com, @NirviShah or nshah@politico.com.

                                            By 
                                                    Nicholas G. Karambelas


                                            By 
                                                    Andrea Damewood


                                            By 
                                                    Sara Solovitch


                                            By 
Todd S. Purdum

Caitlin Emma is an education reporter for POLITICO Pro. Prior to reporting, she was a senior Web producer for Pro.
Caitlin graduated from the University of Connecticut in 2011 and spent a year in a journalism fellowship covering everything in the Nutmeg State – from policy and politics, to police, courts, community book clubs and restaurant health inspections.
She also donated her bone marrow in 2010 and has spearheaded a number of bone marrow donor drives. Ask her about it, and she’ll gladly convince you to register as a donor.
Caitlin is a native of Leominster, Mass.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: Rankings best Education Department — Cool clock, Ahmed — Children in poverty
title: Education a no-show at GOP debate
orgs: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
